intro: Quiina acutangula, commonly known as the narrow-leaved quina, is a flowering plant native to South America, particularly Argentina and Chile. It belongs to the family Geraniaceae and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and narrow, lance-shaped leaves. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky environments and is adapted to withstand arid conditions. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain numerous seeds. Due to its unique morphology and ecological niche, Quiina acutangula is of interest in botanical studies and conservation efforts.
